text: Family Member: Yeah. You, you supply pill or do we have to use our insurance? Doctor: We supply the pills. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Doctor: Yeah same with uh the study is to see if a second pill helps this pill work better so if you’re in the group that gets the second pill, we provide that too. Family Member: Okay. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time.

text: Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct.

text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we do it in this order for everybody. Patient: Okay. Is the castration, the two years, I understand that is standard care. Are there ever any times when that is shortened or – I understand in my case that is likely two years – I accept that that’s what it’s going to be. Doctor: Okay, okay. Family Member: Is that even in case number three, though, the aggressive with the chemo and the super hormone, or is the hormone; I just want to ask In standard care two you said the hormone shot would be for two years. In the third option with the chemo, how long is that going to be last? Doctor: So the way we’re doing it, it’s still two years. Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting.

text: Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
